sn35.237:0.3: 237. The Simile of Hands and Feet (2nd)
sn35.237:1.1: “Mendicants, when there are hands, there’s picking up and putting down.
sn35.237:1.2: When there are feet, there’s coming and going.
sn35.237:1.3: When there are joints, there’s contracting and extending.
sn35.237:1.4: When there’s a belly, there’s hunger and thirst.
sn35.237:1.5: In the same way, when there’s an eye, pleasure and pain arise internally conditioned by eye contact.
sn35.237:1.6: When there’s an ear … nose … tongue … body …
sn35.237:1.7: mind, pleasure and pain arise internally conditioned by mind contact.
sn35.237:2.1: When there are no hands, there’s no picking up and putting down.
sn35.237:2.2: When there are no feet, there’s no coming and going.
sn35.237:2.3: When there are no joints, there’s no contracting and extending.
sn35.237:2.4: When there’s no belly, there’s no hunger and thirst.
sn35.237:2.5: In the same way, when there’s no eye, pleasure and pain don’t arise internally conditioned by eye contact.
sn35.237:2.6: When there’s no ear … nose … tongue … body …
sn35.237:2.7: mind, pleasure and pain don’t arise internally conditioned by mind contact.”
